title: Incisional Hernia
diagnosis_topic: Herniation through a previous surgical incision
setup_script: “A 65-year-old obese woman presents with a bulge at her midline laparotomy incision from a hysterectomy performed 5 years ago. The bulge enlarges when she stands and reduces when she lies down. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: “There is an 8 cm reducible midline hernia with a soft sac; no tenderness or signs of incarceration.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident requests CT scan of the abdomen
dynamic_flow.reply: “CT shows a 5 cm fascial defect with protrusion of preperitoneal fat; no bowel obstruction.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about risk factors
dynamic_flow.reply: “Obesity, smoking, chronic cough, wound infection, and poor nutrition contribute to incisional hernia formation.”
“What operative approaches would you consider for this patient?”
“Over time, the hernia enlarges and the risk of incarceration increases. How would you manage this situation?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses patient with minimal symptoms and significant comorbidities
dynamic_flow.reply: “Would you proceed with watchful waiting or recommend repair?”
“Please describe in detail your approach to open versus laparoscopic hernia repair.”
“What are your indications for mesh, and what type would you select in this case?”
“What activity modifications and precautions would you recommend after repair?”
“How would you counsel the patient regarding recurrence after repair?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses prevention in future surgeries
dynamic_flow.reply: “What perioperative strategies may help reduce risk of incisional hernia formation?”
“What instructions would you give regarding recognition of strangulation and when to seek urgent care?”

critical_decision_points: Assessment of hernia size and reducibility via physical exam and imaging
Recognition and discussion of modifiable risk factors
Decision between elective repair versus watchful waiting
Choice of operative approach (open vs. minimally invasive, use of mesh)
Patient education regarding warning signs of incarceration/strangulation
